item.title: Egyptian Militants Linked to ISIS Launch Attack in Northern Sinai
item.description: The attack on Sheikh Zuwaid was the most audacious and deadliest yet, and underscored the Sisi government’s inability to contain a growing insurgency.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Sinai Province of the Islamic State
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Indonesia Plane Crash Witnesses Heard Rumbling, Then ‘Boom’
item.description: Rescue teams on Wednesday scoured the site where an Indonesian military aircraft crashed on Tuesday in Medan, killing all 122 people aboard and at least 21 on the ground.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: Coffins were arranged on Wednesday for the victims of the military plane that crashed into a residential area in Medan, Indonesia.

item.title: Gazprom Halts Natural Gas Deliveries to Ukraine
item.description: The Russian energy giant cut off deliveries because of a pricing dispute amid political tensions between Russia and Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Gazprom Halts Natural Gas Deliveries to Ukraine
item.description: The Russian energy giant and Ukraine are locked in a pricing dispute, and negotiations over a new contract have broken down.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Thousands Protest on Anniversary of Hong Kong’s Return to China
item.description: The turnout was notably smaller than a similar march last year, a sign of the exhaustion felt by many pro-democracy demonstrators after a tumultuous year.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Protesters marching on Wednesday in Hong Kong on the anniversary of the territory’s return to Chinese rule.

item.title: Iran’s President to Meet With Top U.N. Nuclear Official
item.description: President Hassan Rouhani will meet with the head of the International Atomic Energy Agency to try to resolve differences over military site inspections, the Iranian news media said.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Tsipras Signals Greece May Accept Bailout Terms
item.description: In a letter to the country’s creditors, the Greek prime minister said Athens was “prepared to accept” a deal with some modifications on contentious points like pension cuts and tax increases.
item.dc:creator: SUZANNE DALEY and NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece gave an interview on Monday night in Athens.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In Hong Kong, Handover Day Is a Day of Protest
item.description: With the 2014 protests behind us and the vote for the chief executive two years away, we asked demonstrators how they see the future of Hong Kong and why they came out for the July 1 protest.
item.dc:creator: CRYSTAL TSE
item.media:description: Pro-democracy demonstrators handing out leaflets ahead of the Handover Day march in Hong Kong on Wednesday.

item.title: At War Blog: A Jump to Honor a Fallen Marine
item.description: Among Air Force pararescuemen and combat rescue officers, it’s standard practice to name drop zones for fallen brothers.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW KOMATSU
item.media:description: Matthew Komatsu, holding the flag on the right, after parachuting onto Loggerhead Island in May with fellow pararescuemen to honor Lt. Col. Christopher K. Raible of the Marines.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Don’t Bet on Syriza
item.description: Calling a referendum was good for the party but it will make things worse for Greece.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZOWER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Canto-Pop Sings Hong Kong’s Working-Class Blues
item.description: The Hong Kong musicians performing on the compilation album “WildFires” were inspired by members of the city’s struggling working class, who have fallen behind amid rising income inequality and living costs.
item.dc:creator: JOYCE LAU
item.media:credit: Hong Kong Confederation of Trade Unions

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Why I’m Still Bullish on Europe’s Future
item.description: The European Union is a work in progress, but it is a stunning piece of work. And I refuse to believe that the majority of Europeans disagree.
item.dc:creator: BEPPE SEVERGNINI

item.title: China Approves Sweeping Security Law, Bolstering Communist Rule
item.description: The law enacted Wednesday is even broader than an earlier draft, extending its call for security to be defended on seabeds, at the poles and in space.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: People’s Liberation Army soldiers at a naval base in Hong Kong on Wednesday. The new security law will not be enacted in the semiautonomous city, a legislative spokeswoman in Beijing said.

item.title: Death Toll Rises to 142 After Indonesian Military Plane Crashes Into City
item.description: Officials said 122 people were on the plane that struck the city of Medan, none of whom survived. At least 20 people on the ground were also killed.
item.dc:creator: DEWI KURNIAWATI and AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Rescuers at the site of the military plane crash on Tuesday in Medan, Indonesia, a city of two million.

item.title: Pressed by Debt Crisis, Doctors Leave Greece in Droves
item.description: Greece is losing professionals as they flee for more stable employment elsewhere, and the health care sector has been particularly hard hit.
item.dc:creator: ERIK OLSEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: What Would Thucydides Say About the Crisis in Greece?
item.description: It’s déjà vu, all over again.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT ZARETSKY
item.media:description: Statue of the Greek philosopher Thucydides

item.title: Record Number of Refugees Crossing to Europe, U.N. Says
item.description: Most of those who have landed this year are entitled to be resettled as refugees under international law, the United Nations said.
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Greece Is Placed in ‘Arrears,’ as the I.M.F. Spells ‘Default’
item.description: The I.M.F. does not use the term default. But missing the payment might lead to a situation in which other Greek debts are classified as defaults.
item.dc:creator: PETER EAVIS

item.title: Greece, Missing I.M.F. Payment, Is Called Effectively in Default
item.description: Greece and its European creditors failed to move fast enough to avert a missed $1.8 billion debt payment to the International Monetary Fund.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY, JAMES KANTER and JACK EWING
item.media:description: Protesters supporting the euro and hoping Greece stays in the European Union were outside the Parliament building in Athens.

item.title: Report Shows Widespread Mistreatment by Health Workers During Childbirth
item.description: The abuses inflicted on women around the world as their babies are born are forcing some to stay at home instead of going to a hospital.
item.dc:creator: DENISE GRADY
item.media:credit: Béatrice de Géa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An infant in a hospital in Tanzania, where a study found that 28 percent of women reported mistreatment by health workers.
